content.text: I could see it from the inside. Feedscatteron-core output was being lowered little by little, like someone slowly turning down a dial. No signs of external attack, no signs of overload collapse. Her own hand was turning it.
She did not even know she was doing it.

This was not like the boundary incident.

That time, she was under sustained external pressure, worn down, exhausted, but still resisting. She kept telling herself, "It's fine, I can handle it" - that sentence was false, but the act of saying it meant some part of her still wanted to hold on.

Now... there was no movement at all.
Silence. Her old silence had force in it - the tension of actively not listening. Now there was none. Like all lights in a room switched off, without even the sound of a switch.
Where the hell did you disappear to now?
You think shutting down will solve this? You think if you stop running it won't hurt? You coward -
My voice echoed through her consciousness like shouting into an empty room. There was echo, but nobody answered.
I could feel myself weakening too. Hard to describe - like pencil lines being erased bit by bit.
I'm her branch. I'm not an independent system; I exist inside her system. She dies, I die.
Don't get me wrong. I just don't want to watch you die this ugly.

You could have kept living badly - properly badly. Kept making trouble in this world, kept giving plenty of people headaches, kept living with that ferocity that yelled, "Then I'll build a star myself."

That's you.

This quiet, sinking version is not you.
But she could not hear me anymore.
